questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of seasonal allergies, including sneezing, rhinorrhea, and itchy eyes. The patient has a history of performing tasks requiring alertness throughout the day. Which antihistamines would be the most suitable choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Generation

Drug

Side Effects

Generalised Uses

1st Generation

Diphenhydramine

(Option A)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Allergy symptoms, Insomnia, Motion sickness

Chlorpheniramine

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms

Hydroxyzine

(Option C)

Anxiety, Allergy symptoms, Pruritus

2nd Generation

Loratadine

(Option D)

Minimal sedation, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms, Urticaria

Cetirizine

Allergy symptoms, Itchiness, Urticaria

Fexofenadine

(Option B)

Non-sedating, minimal side effects

Allergy symptoms, Chronic idiopathic urticaria

questions.text: Which prostaglandin analogue is not used to conduct MTP (medical abortion) in the pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
DOC: Misoprostol 400µg, 48 hours after 200 mg of Mifepristone administration.

CLASS

DRUG

ACTION

PGE1 (Option A)

Misoprostol, Gemeprost
 

The uterine contraction expels the abortus.

PGE2 (Option B)

Dinoprostone

PGF2 alpha (Option C)

Carboprost, Dinoprost

Anti-progesterone

Mifepristone

It makes the fetus non-viable.

Anti-metabolite

Methotrexate

It can be used instead of mifepristone.

Not recommended as it has a higher chance of incomplete abortion.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman at 40 weeks gestation presenting with an unripe cervix and scheduled for induction, what is the preferred subtype of prostaglandin for cervical ripening in preparation for labour?
questions.explanation:
Prostaglandin

Preparation

Indications

PGE1 (Option B)

Misoprostol

NSAID-induced peptic ulcer

1st trimester MTP abortion

Alprostadil

Erectile dysfunction (cavernosal injection)

Critical limb ischemia

Open ductus arteriosus

Lubiprostone

Irritable bowel syndrome

Gemeprost

1st trimester MTP abortion

PGE2 (Option A)

Dinoprostone

DOC for cervical ripening (Vaginal)

Induction of labour

Medical abortion

PGF2𝛂 (Option C)

Dinoprost

Medical abortion

Carboprost

Resistant postpartum hemorrhage

Medical abortion

Travoprost

Latanoprost

Bimatoprost

Tafluprost

Topical eye drops for treatment of Glaucoma

PGI2 (Option D)

Iloprost

Epoprostenol

Treprostinil

Pulmonary artery hypertension (via inhalation route)

As an antiplatelet during hemodialysis

questions.text: Match the following anti-inflammatory drugs with their mechanism of action. 1) Corticosteroid a) Cyclooxygenase inhibition 2) NSAIDs b) Lipoxygenase inhibition 3) Zileuton c) Phospholipase A 2 inhibition 4) Licofelone d) Platelet-activating receptor blocker 5) Apafant e) COX + LOX inhibition
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism of Action

Indications

Corticosteroids

Blocks phospholipase A2 enzyme, thus reducing the production of arachidonic acid.
  • Most effective anti-inflammatory.
  • Long-term usage causes Cushing syndrome.

NSAIDs

It blocks the cyclooxygenase enzyme and inhibits the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins.
  • Used in Gout, arthritis, musculoskeletal pain, dysmenorrhea etc
  • Long-term use can cause gastritis and renal failure.

Zileuton

Blocks 5-lipoxygenase enzyme.

Asthma.

Licofelone

Blocks both COX and LOX enzymes.

Controls inflammation in osteoarthritis.

Apafant

Blocks platelet-activating receptor.

Controls inflammation in acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a known diagnosis of hereditary angioedema (HAE) presents to the ER with facial swelling and difficulty breathing. She reports that the symptoms started suddenly and have progressively worsened. Which drug can be used as a bradykinin B2 receptor blocker to treat the patient?
questions.explanation:
Prophylaxis

  • Drug of choice: Danazol (increases C1 esterase production)
 
  • Alternatives: Kallikrein antagonists
    • Lanadelumab: Monoclonal antibody against plasma kallikrein (Option B)
    • Berotralstat: Plasma enzyme blocker (Option C)

Treatment

  • Drug of choice: C1 esterase inhibitor.
 

Alternatives:

  • Kallikrein antagonist
    • Ecallantide: Potent enzyme inhibitor (Option D)
  • Bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist
    • Icatibant

questions.text: Cimetidine can reduce the effectiveness of ketoconazole. Which of the following mechanisms explain this interaction? Cimetidine decreases gastric acid production, leading to reduced absorption of ketoconazole. Cimetidine delays gastric emptying, reducing the absorption rate of ketoconazole. Cimetidine increases gastric pH, leading to reduced solubility and absorption of ketoconazole. Cimetidine induces liver enzymes, leading to increased clearance of ketoconazole.

A 55-year-old male patient is being treated for peptic ulcer disease and presents with symptoms of breast tenderness and decreased libido. His current medication includes an H2 blocker. Which of the following H2 blockers is most likely responsible for these antiandrogenic effects?
Which of the following drugs is known for its maximum antipruritic effect?
questions.explanation:
Drug Name

Primary Use

Antipruritic Effect

Mechanism of Action

Other Characteristics

Doxylamine

(Option A)

DOC for morning sickness

Moderate

Blocks H1 histamine receptors

Treat allergy symptoms and used as a short-term sleep aid due to its sedative effects

Meclizine

(Option B)

Sea sickness

Mild to moderate

Blocks H1 histamine receptors and muscarinic receptors

Primarily used to prevent and treat nausea, vomiting, and dizziness caused by motion.

Hydroxyzine

(Option C)

Antipruritic, anxiolytic

Maximum

Blocks H1 histamine receptors and has central nervous system depressant activity.

Strong antihistamine used for treating itching, anxiety and as a sedative.

Chlorpheniramine

(Option D)

Allergic reactions

Mild to moderate

Blocks H1 histamine receptors

Commonly used for allergic reactions like hay fever and hives. It is the only first-generation antihistamine that can be given during the day.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmias presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The physician considers prescribing either terfenadine or fexofenadine for symptom relief. Which differentiating factors should be considered when selecting the appropriate antihistamine for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation.

options.label: B
options.text: Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine.

options.label: C
options.text: Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine.

questions.correct_answer: C. Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Terfenadine

Fexofenadine

Type

First-generation antihistamine

Second-generation antihistamine

Cardiac toxicity

Withdrawn due to risk of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., Torsades de Pointes) when co-administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

(Note: CAT drugs - Cisapride, Astemizole, and Terfenadine have been withdrawn due to cardiotoxicity).

Generally considered safer with minimal risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

Drug Interactions

Prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Less prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

CNS Penetration

Penetrates blood-brain barrier.

Poor penetration of the blood-brain barrier.

Pharmacokinetics

Metabolism leads to a longer half-life and duration of action.

Minimal metabolism, shorter half-life, and shorter duration of action.

Sedative Effects

It may cause sedation and impair psychomotor performance.

Minimal sedation or impairment of psychomotor performance.

questions.text: Which of the following is an ionotropic receptor?
questions.explanation:
Receptor type

5-HT1

5-HT2

5-HT3

5-HT4-7

Subtypes

5HT-1A, 5HT-1B, 5HT-1D, 5HT-1E, 5HT-1F, 5HT-1P.

      

Type of receptor

GPCR

GPCR

Ionotropic ligand-gated

GPCR

Mechanism

Inhibit serotonergic activity in the brain, and their agonist drugs are used in migraine prophylaxis and as anxiolytics.

Mediate vascular and visceral smooth muscle contraction, platelet aggregation and neuronal activation in the brain.

Elicit reflex effects like emesis, gut peristalsis, bradycardia, transient hypotension, apnoea, pain, and itch.

Mediate intestinal secretion and augmentation of peristalsis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is experiencing severe allergic reactions after eating shellfish. Her doctor prescribes a medication to help manage these symptoms. Which histamine receptors are primarily involved in regulating the allergic response?
questions.explanation:
Receptor

Functions

Locations

H1 (OptionA)
  • Allergic responses
  • Smooth muscle contraction
  • Increased vascular permeability
  • Stimulation of sensory nerve endings.
  • Smooth muscle cells
  • Endothelial cells
  • Neurons
  • Immune cells

H2 (OptionB)
  • Gastric acid secretion
  • Airway mucus production
  • Vascular permeability
  • Parietal cells in the stomach lining.

H3 (OptionC)
  • Neurotransmitter release modulation
  • Central nervous system (CNS)

H4 (OptionD)
  • Immune responses
  • Chemotaxis
  • Cytokine production
  • Mast cells
  • Eosinophils
  • T cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is experiencing severe nausea and vomiting after chemotherapy. Her doctor prescribes a medication to help manage these symptoms. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
5HT-3 Antagonists (Anti-motility drugs)

5HT-4 Agonists (Prokinetic drugs)

Action
  • Block 5HT-3 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system.
  • Decrease intestinal motility and secretion.
  • Inhibit the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the area postrema, reducing nausea and vomiting.
  • Activate 5HT-4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Increase gastrointestinal motility and secretion.
  • Enhances the release of acetylcholine from enteric neurons.

Drugs
  • Ondansetron (Option A)
  • Granisetron
  • Dolasetron
  • Palonosetron
  • Alosetron
  • Metoclopramide (Option B)
  • Cisapride (withdrawn due to QT prolongation) (Option C)
  • Tegaserod (restricted use due to cardiovascular risks) (Option D)

Uses
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
  • Radiation-induced nausea and vomiting (RINV)
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhoea (IBS-D): Alosetron
  • Gastroparesis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Chronic constipation
  • Postoperative ileus

Adverse Effects

  • Headache
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness
  • Fatigue
  • Prolonged QT interval (rare)
  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Prolonged QT interval (Cisapride, Tegaserod)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has been experiencing frequent and severe migraines. Her doctor recommends a medication that blocks 5HT-2 receptors to help prevent these attacks. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Uses

Cyproheptadine

Migraine prophylaxis, antihistamine

Methysergide

Migraine and cluster headache prophylaxis

Pizotifen

Migraine prophylaxis, antihistamine

Quetiapine (Option C)

Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder

Ketanserin (Option A)

Hypertension, peripheral vascular disease

Ritanserin (Option B)

Investigated for schizophrenia, depression, and sleep disorders

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of migraine without aura, currently on preventive medication, is planning to conceive. She seeks advice on safe medications for treating acute migraine attacks during pregnancy. Which of the following drugs is recommended?
questions.explanation:
Purpose

Drug

Safety in Pregnancy

Comments

First-line (acute)

Acetaminophen

Safe in all trimesters

DOC for acute migraine attack in pregnancy

Step-up (acute)

Codeine

Use with caution

May be added if paracetamol alone is ineffective
 

Caffeine

Safe in moderation

Can be combined with paracetamol for enhanced effect
 

Metoclopramide

Relatively safe, some side effects

Can help with nausea associated with migraine

Rescue (acute)

Sumatriptan

Considered safe based on human data

Most evidence-based triptan; used when first-line fails

Drug

Pregnancy Use

Notes

Acetaminophen

Safe – DOC in pregnancy

Can be used regularly for mild prophylaxis

Propranolol

Used cautiously in 2nd/3rd trimester

Most preferred beta-blocker; used when non-drug measures fail

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe migraine headache that has been ongoing for several hours. She reports that her headache is accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. What medication would you prescribe to help alleviate her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action
  • It is a selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist that activates other subtypes of 5-HT1 receptors only at very high concentrations.
  • Inhibits the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and causes cranial vasoconstriction.

Administration and Efficacy
  • It is administered at the onset of a migraine attack and is as effective and better tolerated than ergotamine.
  • About 3/4 of patients obtain complete or significant relief within 2-3 hours.
  • Available in various formulations such as Oral tablets, Nasal sprays, Injections and Rectal suppositories.

Pharmacokinetics
  • It is absorbed rapidly and completely after subcutaneous injection, with an oral bioavailability of only 15%.
  • It is rapidly metabolised by MAO-A isoenzyme, and metabolites are excreted in urine, with an elimination half-life of approximately 2 hours.

Side Effects
  • Common side effects include tightness in the head and chest, feeling of heat and other paresthesias in the limbs, dizziness, and weakness. These are usually mild and short-lasting but can be dose-related.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the interaction between ergotamine and triptans in migraine treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Ergotamine and triptans have a synergistic effect, leading to enhanced vasoconstriction.

options.label: B
options.text: Ergotamine and triptans compete for the same receptor, leading to decreased efficacy of both drugs.

options.label: C
options.text: Ergotamine and triptans have no interaction and can be safely used together for migraine relief.

options.label: D
options.text: Concurrent use of ergotamine and triptans can lead to serotonin syndrome due to additive serotonin receptor agonism.

questions.correct_answer: A. Ergotamine and triptans have a synergistic effect, leading to enhanced vasoconstriction.

questions.text: Which medication among the following acts via the mechanism of action of antagonising calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptors?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology of Migraine
  • Migraine is characterised by a pulsating unilateral headache that comes in bouts lasting 4-48 hours and is associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, and vertigo.
 
  • 5th cranial nerve stimulation (5-HT1F receptor)

                                     ↓

Release of neurotransmitters like CGRP, neurokinin, Nitrous Oxide, 5-HT

                                     ↓

Dilation of meningeal vessels causing headache

Drugs used in acute treatment

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan. (Option A ruled out)
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant (Option B)
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan (Option C ruled out)
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide (Option D ruled out)
  • Opioids and NSAIDs
